executive_summary: Indian-Americans represent the second-largest Asian-American community in the United States, with 4.4 million people. Despite making up nearly 1.5% of the US population, the number of Indian restaurants is still relatively modest. The surprisingly low penetration of Indian restaurants in the country reflects the characteristics of Indian immigrants in the United States. Most Indian immigrants are highly skilled and work in professional jobs, creating a shortage of nonprofessional jobs like chefs. Nonetheless, the increasing popularity of Indian culture and rising income levels, especially among this ethnic group, have boosted demand for Indian restaurants. Overall, industry revenue is expected to climb at a CAGR of 2.1% to $4.9 billion over the past five years, including a 1.4% growth in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: A Shortage in Service Sector Labor Results in a Low Number of Indian Restaurants
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Like other restaurants, profit for Indian restaurants is relatively slim due to high purchase costs and intense price competition. Therefore, profit is expected to make up 4.7% of revenue in 2024. Indian restaurants must source spices from foreign suppliers, thus exposing them to price volatility and logistics disruptions amid the pandemic. Over the next five years, Indian cuisine will continue capturing more interest from foodies, including those from other ethnicities. Curries, biriyanis and naans have been featured in multiple must-eat lists, further contributing to the growing popularity of Indian cuisine. So industry revenue is expected to grow at a CAGR of 1.7% to $5.3 billion over the five years to 2029.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: While Still Underrepresented Compared to the Size of the Indian Community, Restaurants are on the Rise
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Immigration used to be largely limited to European countries, but an immigration policy change in the 1960s welcomed a wave of Indian immigrants to the United States. Many Indian immigrants come to the US via employment-based visas in tech industries, so they tend to be English-proficient and degree-holders, enabling them to work in professional jobs. With higher education levels, only 5.0% of Indian immigrants work in the service sector, which is much lower compared to that of native Americans and all other immigrants. By contrast, 80.0% of Indian immigrants participate in the management, business, science, and arts occupations, according to the Migration Policy Institute. The continued surge in Indian immigrants to the United States and their growing income have prompted more Indian restaurants to enter the industry. future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Fine Dining Indian Restaurants Provide a New Demand Source
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: In 2023, three Indian restaurants in the US, including Rania, Semma and Indienne, received Michelin stars. This has marked a significant move of Indian cuisine in the US fine-dining gastronomy map as the Michelin Guide is one of the world's highly ranked restaurant lists. So restaurants with a Michelin star are expected to welcome more customers, benefiting the industry. Sona in New York City, owned by celebrity Priyanka Chopra, has also garnered much attention since its opening. For instance, the restaurant has been frequented by many Hollywood stars like Sophie Turner, Kal Penn and Mindy Kaling, according to HELLO! India.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Immigration Trends Will Bode Well With Industry Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The United States is expected to continue welcoming more Indian immigrants over the next five years, many of whom will likely work in professional occupations. According to the US Census, households with Indian ancestry have average earnings of $150,000, much higher than other immigrants and ethnic groups. Therefore, a growing Indian community will provide an expanding customer base for the industry.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry sell Indian food through take-out, delivery and sit-down dining. This industry excludes food offered by food trucks.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: Low - Steady

key_trends: Indian restaurants have an underrepresented presence in the United States despite the strong share of the Indian community in the country. The modest concentration of Indian immigrants and Indian-Americans in the service sector has resulted in a low number of Indian restaurants.
The continued wave of Indian immigrants will bode well with industry growth in the future. With more immigrants, many of whom work in highly paid positions, demand for Indian food will benefit.

Indian restaurants are subject to laws and regulations regarding food preparation and sale, including product safety, nutritional content and menu labeling. The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is the industry's primary source of guidance and regulation.

Indian restaurants don't receive direct government aid or monetary compensation. However, associations like the National Restaurant Association and the National Council of Chain Restaurants support the food service sector.
High-income earners spend most generously on fine-dining full-service restaurants. Conversely, lower-income individuals tend to frequent fast-casual establishments.
Sit-down services bring in the highest revenue share of Indian restaurants. But more customers have been ordering delivery and take-out food.
The industry is highly competitive, with restaurants competing on prices and food offerings. Low product differentiation has resulted in intense price competition for Indian restaurants.
Indian restaurants face competition from home-cooked and prepackaged meals as health-conscious consumers increasingly opt for meals that fit dietary and budgetary limits.
Profit for this industry is slim as price competition limits restaurant operators' ability to raise prices. As inflation has pushed up purchase costs, profit will likely suffer in the short-term.

The industry also faces pressure with chef burnout, which potentially leads to a labor shortage in the future. But many have offered competitive remuneration packages to attract chefs entering the industry.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Households with earnings over $150,000 have the budget to spend more generously on food away from home. In general, these individuals are also time-strapped, limiting their ability to prepare home meals.

Despite not making up the largest revenue share, middle-income earners contribute a stable source of industry revenue. Individuals in this segment are generally employed, increasing the chance that they'll purchase food from Indian restaurants.
This customer group includes low-income earners, restricting their ability to frequent Indian restaurants. Many of these customers tend to forgo dining out when income falls.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: On Premise Dining Fell Significantly Amid the Pandemic
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Amid the pandemic, all dining areas were required to close or operate at a reduced capacity, depressing revenue generated from dine-in services. As the restrictions were lifted, revenue from this service has recovered.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Although the economy has improved from the pandemic and people have returned to work, dining traffic is still below pre-pandemic levels. More customers have become accustomed to take-out services as the employment rate improves.
Income-restricted customers tend to visit fast-casual or fast-food Indian restaurants. Conversely, those with more income will likely visit restaurants with table services.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit is Slim for Indian Restaurants
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Like other restaurant industries, profit for the industry is slim. High purchase and wage expenses keep profit from expanding. Simultaneously, fierce price competition also restricts Indian restauranteurs' ability to raise prices.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: All operational aspects of a restaurant business require labor, from serving customers to preparing and cooking food. As a result, the industry is labor-intensive, with wages representing the second-largest expense for Indian restauranteurs.
Labor intensity is high because the industry heavily depends on direct labor input across all operations.

The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Industry revenue is sensitive to broader economic performance
volatility_points.volatility_description: Changes in income levels affect demand for Indian restaurants as the food offered by these establishments is highly discretionary.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Changes in employment patterns also contribute to revenue volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Higher employment rates increase demand for food offered by the industry as customers become time-strapped. Simultaneously, they have more money to spend on outside food when employed.

FAQs.question: What is the revenue volatility for this industry?
FAQs.answer: The revenue volatility for this industry is HIGH. Industry revenue is sensitive to broader economic performance. Changes in income levels and employment patterns affect demand for Indian restaurants as the food offered is highly discretionary and customers become time-strapped when employed.
